name: Why should we care what frogs eat?
description:
What can frogs and toads do for us?

Join Seshadri as he shows us how the amphibians that we often label as creepy crawlies actually play a vital role as part of our food chain, quietly protecting our crops. Sharing insights from his research into how a rich diversity of frogs and toads helps sustain our ecosystems and agricultural landscapes. He will explore their vital role as natural pest controllers and how they could be a powerful antidote to the excessive spraying of pesticides. The talk will also have an interactive component where he will show how a healthy frog population is directly linked to the food we eat through a short game.

name: The Story of Food: Past, Present, Futures
description:
How do our food choices affect us? How do they shape our societies and our environment? What is eating healthy? 

Join Gurmeet Singh as he explores these questions by tracing our history with food from hunter-gatherers, the dawn of agriculture to the different agricultural revolutions and future science like 3D printing, bioreactors, microbiomics, and nutrigenetics. Gurmeet will further dive into how our food choices have affected us, our society and our planet, going through 3 million years of food history.

name: Archiving Kitchen Heirlooms: Documenting Culinary Heritage
description:
How do you capture the story behind your favourite dish?

Join Seher Krishna in a series of guided activities that will explore how to use everyday technology to create a rich, multi-layered archive of a recipe that captures not just flavour, but memory and history. Leave the workshop with the ability to begin building your own family food archive.

name: Seeds of Expression
description:
How can knowledge be passed down through a seed?

Join Arunkumar HG and Dayananda Nagaraju, exhibiting artists of CALORIE, as they explore their exhibits in detail.

Learn about the Akshatha Seedbank with Arunkumar as he shares how it became the foundation of the exhibit Vulnerable Guardians. Discover how this collection of seeds is a living archive of resilience, biodiversity, and cultural memory. Arunkumar will further dive into the ties between farmers, landscapes and seeds, while reflecting on how a seedbank can be a container of knowledge and wisdom from those who came before.

Dayananda will reflect on the artistic process behind his exhibit, Atantraru & The Golden Seed. He reflects on how a thought begins like a seed—small, invisible, and full of potential—and how it finds its way into expression through his artistic practice. Dayananda explores the ecology of creativity, the conditions that allow ideas to germinate, the fragility and resilience of expression, and the collective fields in which thoughts grow. Come and learn how an artwork - just like a seed - can carry memory and possibility!

name: Yuck to Yum! Insects for future food
description:
Would you eat insects?

Join Priyan and the Insect Biosystematics and Conservation Lab team as they brings us into the world of edible insects. Understand how insects are not only a nutritious alternative to fish and meat but also an environmentally sustainable option for the future. Explore India’s rich but undervalued traditions of insect eating, highlight the cultural and medicinal uses of insects, and discuss how commercial rearing can provide livelihood opportunities while contributing to insect conservation. Learn why organisations like the FAO have identified insects as one of the most promising food resources to meet global nutritional needs. 

Step into a world where 'yuck' turns into 'yum' and discover the future of food through an interactive insect tasting session.

name: South America in Our Bellies
description:
What is the history behind the vegetables that we eat?

Our diets contain many plant based foods, taking the form of a diversity of fruits and vegetables. These vegetables and fruits all have unique journeys before they end up on our plates. 

Join Ganesan as he explores the origin stories of our favorite plant based foods travelling from all over the country and even different lands before landing on our plates. Learn what our ancestors ate, when they ate it and how it has changed our lives today.

name: Tales of Ragi
description:
What can we learn from a simple Ragi plant?

Join artist Surekha as she shares her experience of making ‘ragi.net’ - an exhibit displayed as part of CALORIE - through an interactive workshop. Participants will be invited to share their stories about Ragi in the urban context to uncover the lived and historic stories and experience of ragi, its journey between the rural and the urban contexts. Subramani, an artist from the farming community, will also join the workshop and share his experience of being both a farmer and artist, through his drawings and lived experiences. Participants will also learn to make a dish out of a recipe from ragi, from the very harvest extract ragi which she has grown for the CALORIE Exhibition. Explore the entire cycle of ragi, from seed to a fully grown plant, extracted and consumed.
